etymology.description: Pictogram—tripod/ancient bronze vessel with three legs used for cooking or ritual sacrifices; later phonetically (and perhaps semantically) borrowed for “to divine” (then written as 鼑 > 貞).
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a three-legged bronze cauldron used in cooking and ritual, an emblematic vessel in ancient China. The sound was later borrowed for the sense “to divine,” which was separated into different graphs (first 鼑, then standardized as 貞).

examples.chinese: 我们在博物馆看到了青铜鼎(我們在博物館看到了青銅鼎)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen zài bówùguǎn kàn dào le qīngtóng dǐng.
examples.english: We saw a bronze cauldron at the museum.

examples.chinese: 他的话一言九鼎(他的話一言九鼎)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de huà yī yán jiǔ dǐng.

examples.chinese: 祭祀时，他们把食物放入鼎中烹煮(祭祀時，他們把食物放入鼎中烹煮)。
examples.pinyin: Jìsì shí, tāmen bǎ shíwù fàng rù dǐng zhōng pēngzhǔ.
examples.english: During rituals, they put food into the cauldron to cook.
